Description: Base and lid of the anthropoid wooden inner coffin of Hornedjitef, son of Nekhthorheb, who held a large number of priestly offices. Polychrome painted and gilded face, wig, collar and pectoral, winged scarab across breast, body inscribed with vertical registers of painted hieroglyphs, flanked by deities, the rest of the surface is unelaborated. Interior of lid decorated with a figure of Nut, surrounded by astronomical images of decan stars and constellations. Interior of base also decorated.
Curator's comments: The underside of the lid contains depictions of the decan stars and is similar to star clocks from the Middle Kingdom. First appearing inside coffin lids around 2100 BC, the clocks measured the motion of groups of stars that appeared in the eastern sky at dawn every ten days – termed ‘decan’ stars. Arranged in grids of 36 intervals, each interval had 12 stars, one for every hour of the night. Published in: Regulski, I. (ed.), 2022. Hieroglyphs: unlocking ancient Egypt, p. 179
